reviewText:
Ignore the bad reviews if you think this game will interest you.  Its not everyone's cup of tea.  And on top of that, its severely buggy and largely unpolished.  But if you look past all that roughness, there is a true gem in here.  Not many games deliver so well on so much.  It may be one of the best PC games I've ever played.  Consider the following story as a testament to what kind of game this is:

I started out an innkeeper in a large city in a large region.  I was doing okay.  I kept selling cheap food and drink in order to open a bakery nearby.  The bakery was also not much, mostly baking rolls for the masses.  But in time I was doing well financially and took some time off to pursue a love interest.

The same year she was pregnant and gave birth to my first born son.  I was busy working and she spent less time at the bakery.  Soon all her time was spent between the house and the church.  Neither of us minded though.  My son was of school age and we couldn't afford much.  So we sent him to a guild school to study to join the family business.  The same year, my wife was pregnant again, but this time with a little girl.

During this time I was able to afford to be a citizen and was granted the ability to expand my business.  I quickly set up an orchard and a farm outside the gates.  It was hopeful, as the supplies for both the Inn and Bakery were now completely controlled by me.

By the time my daughter was of school age, we had the assets to send her to the best school possible.  My first born son, was not the most amitious child and my first born daughter had a brighter future due to our new financial situation.

I had another daughter, and another son.  More of the same, I suppose, as I was too busy working at the largely successful Inn and expanding my business to fisheries and livestock.

My first born son was a disappointment.  He was born when we were poor and didn't amount to much.  He mostly went to church with his mother and didn't have the skills to follow in the family business.  My first born daughter on the other hand, had the right schooling and was perfectly set up to join the family business.  My second daughter, while successful on her own terms, didn't match the success of the first daughter.  And lastly, my last born child, a boy, was quiet and simply enjoyed school.

When my first born daughter came of age to help out, she did with much ambition.  While I worked the Inn, she helped with apple picking and livestock.  She was maybe a bit too ambitious as she managed the workers with the attitude of a tyrant.  But I was happy with the success of my business and I was running out of room to expand, so I turned to politics.

I managed to win a low level office for a very short time before getting replaced by a man who had leprosy.  However, my daughter almost entirely transitioned my business empire away from me and was doing quite well.  So I kept at it.  I had money to spend, so I intended to use it.  I began bribing people for votes, and I managed to bribe the king himself.  But, I lost again.

While my daughter ran my business, and I was unsuccessful at politics, I had little to do.  So for the most part, I rekindled my relationship with my aging wife.  Also, my character strangely had alcohol in his inventory often, and was no stranger to drinking it on the spot or offering it to others.  On a strange night, I also tried sabotaging a rival bakery by tossing an explosive in the front door.  It was a mistake and didn't do much.

While I declined from power and my daughter took over, I failed to notice my last born son.  He graduated from university with a doctorate.  He was a scholar and was a full grown man ready to open his own line of business.  Upon his graduation, he quickly started a bank and hospital in town.  He worked hard, but being the business man in the family, I saw issues.  Two doors down from his bank was a rival bank.  Around the corner from his hospital, was a rival hospital.

He was happy working and keeping to himself, so I took it upon myself.  We bombed them and ran.  I went home to my wife and all was fine.  Except, it wasn't.

While I was at home with my wife, my son was working late at the hospital, and my daughter was working late night at the Inn, my daughter, unfortunately lead by her father's poor example, carried out a constant barrage of attacks across the entire city for hours.  Many people died, including many of my loyal bodyguards, and several buildings were so heavily damaged they couldn't be entered for fear of collapse.

The tooltip read for me - Corrupt.  My entire life I was a righteous man and in a single day I ruined a lifetime of good.  My daughter however, was labeled a walking nightmare.  A title she wore proudly as she was a violent and cruel woman.

A day later I was summoned to trial for my crimes.  And shortly after, so was my daughter.  Fortunately for me, the persecuter was bad at her job and couldn't articulate my crimes well enough.  With experience, I was able to convince the judges that I was not guilty.  My daughter - the judge didn't even show and she walked free.

I was done, however.  And now my entire business was in the hand's of my daughter and son.

A few short years later my daughter married and had a series of daughters.  My son married and had sons.  She spent most of her time in the Inn, acting as an innocent server as she masterminded violence.  Her first born daughter stayed at home with her father, picking up the skills for crafting.

My son on the other hand built up impressive charismatic skills and began spending most of his time preaching.  He opened his own Catholic church and was busy speaking to the masses.  He wasn't as interested in the hospital anymore due to issues obtaining supplies needed for medicine.  That was, however, one of the catalysts for what happened next.

Illness spread across the city.  It struck the elderly for the most part.  And the political stage was swept clean.

My son saw this as an opportunity to win an easy election and do some good for the city.  So he applied for a entry level political office.

My first born daughter's daughter was also of age and opened up a tailoring shop.  She worked in it night and day and was militant, like her evil mother.  However, she just enjoyed working hard.  She committed no crimes and often gave bonuses to her employees to reward them for putting up with her management style.

My son had only one opponent to beat for political office.  But to help seal the deal, his sister showed up and gave some bribe money to the king.  He won the vote and was now holding political office.  First it was the Leasing Officer.  Then it was the Guild Master.  Then Bishop.  Then he used his political power to help his sister and neice also win politcal offices.

He had charisma and the power of the people behind him.  His sister was a brute with deep pockets.  She kept helping him win and in return, he would give her his vote when she applied.  Together, they made it to the top - Cardinal, Soverign, and my grandaughter was Consul.  Together, they took down bandits, banished rivals, carried out crime and government authority hand in hand.  All while I watched from my estate.  My children took over the city both economically and politcally.  All while in my lifetime.  Not sure if I'm proud or scared.

If you made it this far, kudos for reading.

reviewText:
UPDATED ON APRIL 2, 2016: I promised to come back to this review after playing the latest official patch more, and I can report that bugs still persist.  Having said that, it is still a big improvement over the last vanilla version, and I can also recommend either Fajeth or McCoy's mods to make the game even more playable.  Both do different things, but both are fantastic.  It is my recommendation that you try both (separately - mods generally can't work together in TG2) and definitely use one of them, especially once you've played vanilla for 50 hours or so to get a grasp for the basics of the game.

Onto the review: I will not belabor the point: The Guild is my favorite game.  In this review I’ll try to explain why this is, and where I’m coming from in terms of my interest in the game, and probably games generally speaking.  Hopefully this will help introduce like-minded gamers to The Guild and perhaps also steer some people, if they have different tastes, from the game.

I have always enjoyed simulation games, particularly economic and life sims.  I grew up playing what now seem like fairly simplistic sims (e.g., Theme Park, The Settlers, and The Sims) and was fascinated by the seemingly living world of the AI inhabitants in these games.  As I began to enjoy role playing games more, and in particularly Ultima Online, I longed for a simulation game in which I wasn’t in complete control, but instead could actually be one of those small inhabitants in the simulated world.  Nothing like this existed until I played the first Guild game (Europa 1400) and I was immediately won over, realizing that it was as close to a perfect game as I would ever find, short of developing one myself.

The Guild is indeed a simulated world.  It doesn’t attempt to be huge like Skyrim.  You are controlling a small family in a single town or on some maps a single town out of up to four.  There are up to eleven other “dynasties” (i.e. families) living in these towns, and they all go about their business without your intervention.  You are not god in this game – you are just a family existing and striving in the middle ages, and it is amazing fun.  It seems there is not one area that The Guild has left out of its gameplay.  You can get involved in politics, your character has a religiosity meter, favor (or disfavor) with every single sim in the game, a disposition based on their criminality or lack thereof, skills, perks (think fallout), marriage, children, trials, duals, and the list goes on.

The world in The Guild feels more alive than any game I have played.  NPCs go about their business with a real purpose, and it is all simulated.  They will do everything from sit around town and chat, go to the pub, hire a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, to run for office and command the city guard (who, by the way, are also governed by some degree of AI logic).  In short, the game feels a lot like living in a real, functioning medieval town.

In summary, if you’ve always enjoyed god games, economic sims, and life sims, but wanted to be part of the world rather than the controller of the world – wanted to have to work within the confines of human ability to influence the world (e.g., become mayor and change the law instead of using a hand in the sky to smite someone) then this is the game for you.  If you want complete control over the world and all of its inhabitants then you might not enjoy this as much, but I still say it’s worth a try.

It's December 22, 2014 and a patch just got released for this 4.5 year old game. Whomever these guys are that bought this license are serious about cleaning it up, but the thing is it was already a great title to begin with. Yeah there were some translation problems, and ai issues, and general problems like that, but it wasn't terrible.

Anyways, this game is just great. You play some male or female person set in old timey overseas land (you get to choose the map to play on), and try to stary a dynasty. You find a spouse, make some kids, and play through the generations. Jobs include stuff from politics, farming, to robbing people. You can make buildings like inns, pubs, churches, and so on or eleminate competing dynasties and take over their buildings through violence or cash. You can select your own stats on the dude or chick you're creating and level up skills through actions, so some rpg elements exist.

You got some trading elements in here as well. Own a mine? Send a caravan of ore to the neighboring village to sell, or import the stuff to make your own jewelry factory. Or make armor and weapons and attack villagers with your bandits. You got a lot of options here on what to do as far as playstyle is concerned. It's a sandbox, but you can't just plop buildings down everywhere. Still there's a lot of options to be found and fun to be had by picking this up and giving it a shot. It can be a little daunting to get into, but I ended up having a lot of fun with this and The Guild II. Well mainly vanilla Guild II, but this is just that with more stuff, so if you can decide which version to get, this is the one to grab.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I have ever played in my life, and at the same time one of the worst. How? Bugs. I am recommending this game now because it has, miraculously, been granted a new patch (which you have to set the game to beta to get through Steam, fyi) which I am hearing good things about.

The old bugs, which may still exist -- I'm not sure yet -- were as follows:
#1 - Multiplayer NEVER worked. Even if you connected through Hamachi (the only way to get multiplayer to even connect) the game would desync after 20 ish minutes and your saves would be corrupted so you couldn't even reload and continue. This game is so amazing for multiplayer and this is just a big kick in the gaming nuts.

#2 - There are a lot of smaller game breaking bugs...too numerous to mention. I can give some examples. One time, nobody ever seemed to progress in the political field. Sometimes your characters get jammed and won't move. Sometimes you save the game and it gets corrupted and you lose everything. Just weird things that should work just...don't...and it's hard to predict and once it happens you can't just 'reload' to get around it. That being said, I have played through games that were 8+ hours long before getting screwed by one of these bugs (provided you are playing in single player).

But this game is fantastic if these bugs are fixed.

For one, this game is a mish mash of a bunch of different games. In this game you control your 'family' starting with one guy. It's very RPGish in the sense that each of your family members can level up and apply points to various skills. You can make them better at combat, better at working, better at politicking, etc.

You can get married, have babies, and then once they grow up you can control them and expand your dynasty. The buildings you own get transfered down the generations so your hard work with your first guy isn't lost when he dies of old age (or disease, or murder, or getting thrown in jail forever).

There are different sized maps but generally a map consits of one to three cities of various size. Each city has their own town hall with their own political arena. You can get elected and then move up towards mayor -- each office you can be elected into has different special powers that can be used to improve your family, or hurt others that are in your way. For example, you can banish someone from a city, or throw them in jail, or cause them to lose one of their buildings, etc.

There is a court house and 'law' as well. If you witness someone comitting a crime you gain the ability to testify in court with evidence against them. If you don't like them, you can charge them with a crime and then try to beat them in court. While you can sway the courts with your political favours, the more evidence against you makes this harder so blatently breaking the law or fighting people in town is going to brand you an outlaw and probably killed by the guards or thrown in jail if you comply.

There are four major classes and as you marry and have kids you can train them into different classes so that EVENTUALLY you can access every type of building in the game -- but basically, your character(s) each get to be trained in one of the four classes. One is a kind of farmer, one is a scholar that can get hospitals and such, one is a blacksmith type character that can make weapons and tools, and one is a thief that can create thieves guilds and other buildings that set up traps to rob people transporting goods.

The game also has a free market and prices rise and fall depending on how much of what is being sold. In fact, if one item is sold a lot in one of the cities and not in the other, you can make money by transporting from one city to the other -- provided you have enough muscle to protect your cargo from any thieves setting up on the roads.

Your houses can train guards which you can use as personal muscle, even to overpower actual city guards, or to plot assasination attempts on powerful members of opposing dynasties.

The controls can be a little confusing -- there's a lot of menus you have to learn to use to be able to quickly identify who is who in the city -- but it can all be done.

When you do build up your financial empire, you typically want to build one of every building and supply your buildings with your own productions. You'll get a mine, and refine the ore for your blacksmith who will make the weapons to sell or use, etc.

Some routes are a lot easier to start with than others. I recall that being a farmer won't make you rich, but it's pretty easy to make money with cows. Blacksmiths are very useful but they're hard to make enough money from early on.

And I was never good with thieves, but they can be very powerful later on by preventing other players from trading and leaving all the profit to your dynasty only.

The game is very deep and for that reason you can get lost playing this game for days. In all honesty, if this game had fixed all of its bugs I would have ranked it one of the best games I've ever played.

I am hopeful that this patch has fixed a lot of the bugs and if that's so, I'll probably leave this recommendation as positive. Otherwise, I'll probably remove it or make it negative. Stay tuned!

reviewText:
This is the one you want, not the original.

This stand-alone expansion originated as a fan-made overhaul mod for the original game. What results is the same game you get with The Guild 2, only polished much further and with many new additions. If you visit the Rune Forge forums, you'll see that they are still releasing patches (as mods, silly enough) even though the publisher has ended dev support. The community is also still active, with new posts on the forums each day.

I'm not trying to say that this game is the best thing ever, but it is definitely the only of it's kind. If you appreciate economics, history, sociology, politics, and the like, and you're looking for a somewhat casual strategy game, you should consider this game among the others on your list. If you're thinking of this as a medieval sims-type game or that you will be able to jump right in and start playing, you're going to be disappointed. This is a thinking man's game, and gamers who aren't willing to put up with bugs and take the required hours needed to fully understand the game will be wasting their money. I'm not saying only serious master-race strategy gamers can appreciate this game, or that people who don't like complicated games have bad taste or are dumb; I just think that the way the game is marketed makes it appear to be much more simple than it really is, and that results in a lot of bad reviews that shouldn't have been reviews to begin with.

reviewText:
The Guild II Renaissance is a game that really can't be compared to many other games. It is truly something quite unique.

A fair warning early on in this review, though, is that the game is ridden with bugs that affect gameplay in a variety of ways and the game itself is no longer supported by its creator, meaning official patches will no longer be released and the patch community is devised of the player base, and that is it.

Don't let that daunting news discourage you, though! There's a reason why I recommend this game in stead of calling it a flop not worthy of even having a price tag upon it.

There are two particular patches located within the series of tubes that patch from 4.10 to 4.15, and 4.15 to 4.17b (a beta patch well-worth getting), of which make the normally buggy and slightly aggravating game of The Guild II Renaissance something to flaunt when it rests in your game arsenal.

It fixes more than just a few bugs and adds some minor content that aids in making the currounding environment in-game more adaptive to your playstyle. Also, on another note, internet servers no longer exist to my knowledge and the game must be run through a LAN set-up if you wish to play multiplayer, for instance with Hamachi.

Yes yes, LAN can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ at times, but I have found that a multiplayer LAN session with friends I know all playing this game together is an event we have actually tried to plan doing once every week. It is that good.

Now to game specifics. The Guild II Renaissance allows you to play as a few starting professions ranging from Scholar, Rogue, Patron and Craftsman. Your main character will play as this role and each role gives you a particular set of buildings you may construct to further build your little 'empire', or more-so your family legacy, and with each building comes two upgrades that subsequently get more expensive, but also carry better bonuses like more employee slots and upgraded security factors i.e. water buckets to put out fires faster if your building happens to catch fire, and iron bars to make a robbery take much more time to complete.

At the time of main character creation as well, you are given the opportunity to set some traits higher than others with a few extra trait points and to choose an astrological symbol that gives you a bonus in a particular trait that is associated with the symbol. You may also choose to be Catholic or Protestant, which can also be changes if your local church offers baptising in the 'opposite' religion.

Now off the topic of your main character and on to the other little bits. As I mentioned earlier, you start off with your main character. One can not simply live forever, in theory, correct? Correct! Your character (male or female) must find a partner before his/her years start to come to an end! Together, yee' will conduct holy (or on-the-spot) matrimony and have highly censored sex until a baby pops out the following year. Marrying another character will put that character under your control and will further increase your 'man-power' in the ultimate climb to power. You are also given the opportunity to send your child to a couple schools, one being fairly expensive but also giving him/her more trait points to allocate once he/she becomes of age, and the cheaper one which offers stock trait point accrual.

There is so little time to explain all this game has to offer, but if the information I have given you so far doesn't pique your interest more than a little bit, this game is definitely not for you. If it does, however, I -HIGHLY- recommend purchasing it and letting your friends know about it as well! You can have up to 12 player and NPC factions active in one session, so ultimately, you can have 12 players playing at the same time! Of course, the more players you add, the stronger the connection will need to be, for the game can crash. Advice on this issue I can offer is to always save your game if you feel like you have made a noteworthy accomplishment.

reviewText:
The Guild II: Renaissance (PC) - REVIEW
An honest day’s work no less. God bless.

Welcome to The Guild II: Renaissance, a game developed by Rune Forge and published by Nordic Games in July 2010. The Guild II: Renaissance is one of, if not the best merchant simulators on the market. Don’t be fooled into thinking this is a review for The Guild II. No, no, no. This is a review for the vastly superior The Guild II: Renaissance. A game where you take the role of a single man (or woman), with only a dream and 2000 gold to start a dynasty that will either be remembered as a respected political family, or a dastardly crime syndicate. All while trying to battle through the technical glitches and game breaking bugs.

In The Guild II: Renaissance the aim of the game is quite difficult to explain. The main objective of each game is to wipe out enemy dynasties; however the game is a lot more complicated than that. You have many ways you can wipe out your enemy dynasties, either by death or by reducing their assets to nothing. The way in which this is completed depends on the character class you choose at the beginning of the game. Are you a horribly evil rogue that preys on delivery wagons in order to feed your desire for gold? Or are you a legitimate business owner, trying to make an honest living? Whatever class you decide to choose you won’t be disappointed with the range of content each class has to offer. I found that the easiest class to start out with was in fact the rogue. I could simply assign my gluttonous henchmen into patrol routes where they were automatically pillage any wagon carts that would dare pass my Bandit Lair. In doing this I avoided the micromanaging that The Guild II: Renaissance has to offer. When micromanaging in a Patron or Craftsman role you can use the games auto managing feature. Be warned; this function inside the game is painstakingly awful to use. You will often find businesses not producing anything at all, or buying too much ♥♥♥♥♥ and not putting it to good use. Causing you to lose the game if you’re not paying attention. But hey, did I mention you can marry folk’ and give birth to children that will take over your dynasty once you die?! This is without a doubt one of the best features in The Guild II: Renaissance and is how dynasties prolong their lifespan when your original character meets their eventual demise. Each character has their own levels and sets of skills. When you produce children they will inherit skills from both the mother and the father. This makes the games skills and levelling system actually have meaning and a useful purpose. Having such a rich and deep system in a trading simulation game is quiet the feat to have. Another absolutely great feature layered into The Guild II: Renaissance is the ability to climb the political ladder. Each rank in the political ladder comes with special commands that only a person with a certain political prestige can use. For example - the mayor can set the laws in a town while a guard captain has full control over units in the city. Nobody can be trusted in politics, to climb this political ladder you must bribe, assassinate and lie your way up the ranks in order to gain approval by higher ranked council members. Honestly, this is just a great system that I’ve never seen used in a game like this before.

In the midst of this great gameplay we stumble across the major problems that The Guild II: Renaissance has growing out of it’s almost too good to be true gameplay. To start this off, the game is a technical mess.  As mentioned before the automatic management of business will only work when it decides to, this alienates a large portion of players that may not want to mess around with the micro-managing, especially if you have 12 banks in 3 different cities. Not to mention this game is littered with game breaking bugs that will crash your game with no warning or notice at all, so you will be expected to save often. Dialogue cut scenes don’t add anything to the gameplay except be incredibly annoying due to the lack of a ‘SKIP CUTSCENE’ button. Often at times you will hear random sounds that just have no place in a cut scene however they just keep playing over, and over again. The multiplayer would have been great to play but it just doesn’t ♥♥♥♥ing work, which is a damn shame considering the potential it could have brought the genre.

In short The Guild II: Renaissance is a fun game to be had if you can look past its technical flaws and occasionally bad game design. The maps are great and diverse, and the stories that can be told in this game are endless. Design choices are questionable however the game breaking glitches and bugs are inexcusable. I will be looking forward for The Guild III which is set to be released sometime next year (2016) by Nordic Games. My hopes for the game are that it gives us everything The Guild II: Renaissance had but improves on the visual aspects, while keeping it updated and free from any technical atrocities that this this game suffered from.

+ Innovative gameplay

+Great dynasty system

+Every play through is different

-Lack of proper multiplayer

-Game breaking glitches and bugs

-Bad visuals and animations

reviewText:
Most people will not give this game the time needed to really appreciate it. The games official genre is a 'historic economy simulation' but there are so many other things that can be done...

Basically you pick a class (Patron, Scholar, Rogue or Craftsman), each class has its own line of goods it can produce - the twist being that most products rely on a good or component from another's class to complete its higher end goods (ex; Armorers need cow hides from Patrons to complete leather armor; Churches need lumber from woodcutters to produce their parchments).

But then there is another section of the game where you can rise in political power; its seat you hold has different perks (ex; Guild master can control finance; Head of church controls the tithe; Head of Law can set the severity of trial outcomes) each of these positions can be used for your own personal gain like sending people to the dungeon for a week's time which causes them to miss a court appearance where they might potentially get you convicted of a crime or making them miss an election where you can take their seat). You can also hire henchmen as security, to burn down your rivals' business...all sorts of wicked stuff.

This all comes at a price, which is time. Everything takes time, naturally. Crops take time to grow, then takes time to process crops (raw materials) into, say, wheat flour which would then be used to make bakery items, church items, etc. This brings into play the economy of supply and demand, where if you're smart and resourceful enough, you can corner the market for really large profits in any particular city. Then of course there are the rogues who rob, kindnap and plunder everyone, everywhere.

In short this is a very ambitious game that covers alot of different genres...successfully. The problem with this ambitious project is that it comes at the cost- the price being eye-candy. To say the graphics engine is dated is almost a compliment, but anyone who can appreciate all the stuff jammed into this game will (hopefully) understand that games that are really pretty to look at are really shallow in gameplay.

The game is awesome and very deep, but it's also not for everyone.

THE GOOD
- Innovative blend of role-playing, real-time strategy, and economic-sim genres
- lots of detail and a great medieval atmosphere

THE BAD
- Repetitive gameplay
- Really heavy on micromanagement
- Limited character interaction

The Guild II: Renaissance
I am ashamed to admit that I am only now discovering this gem of a game.

Pros:
Strategy, adventure, role playing & political intrigue all in one!
Incredible replay value
Almost too many options and paths to choose from

Cons:
Downright evil learning curve
A micromanaging nightmare
Lots of minor bugs

If I were to compare this game to others, I'd say it's a combination of 'The Sims Medieval' and 'Stronghold' which results into a wonderfully complex strategic medieval life simulator. You can choose to begin as a humble farmer, a dashing rogue, a dedicated craftsman or a studious scholar. And that's just your day job! You can become involved in politics if you so choose and possibly, with enough effort invested, becoming a member of the ruling class.

All of the above, and more... if you have the patience and determination to learn how the game actually works. There is a tutorial provided, but it's unfortunately lacking in content. Weather it deliberately leaves out so much so we can discover fun little actions ourselves, I don't know, but you will spend a good hour learning how to actually play the game even after playing through the tutorial.

I'd like to have had more character customization. Unlike 'The Sims Medieval' your individual avatar is quite limited in appearance. I can understand this considering your initial character is going to be among the first to die; leaving you with his offspring and offspring of their own to continue building your empire.

When it comes to your dynasty, as it grows in size and scope, it becomes a micromanaging nightmare. There is an AI option for your businesses, but I find it to be less than satisfactory; which results in me having to run each and every establishment I own. It rapidly gets obnoxiously tedious.

There are still quite a few bugs present but none of them, in my experience, seem to be game breaking. They are, at worst, an annoyance.

Overall there are a few things I would have like to have been different (character customization for one), but for the price this game is an absolute steal.

reviewText:
This is not a perfect game, and I doubt it ever will be. It is however one of a kind, there are very few games that feature sandbox mode business building in the 18th century. There is the element of starting up with your preferred business, finding a wife and starting a family - this is pretty much the gameplay of your first generation. As you build up more cash you can buy titles in order to buy more businesses, upgrade your house and also qualify for political offices. Some businesses are better suited to later generations - such as Carpenter, this business will be much more profitable if you also own a woodcutter hut which then can supply the wood needed and sell surplus to the markets (without this the need to buy wood from the expensive markets makes it quite not very profitable).

All level 1 businesses can be levelled up to levelled up (1 - 2 - 3) which offers further production options and perks that can aid production, add workers and even fend off burglars. You can even decide to go a little crazy and start killing people, you will be taken to court and be sent to prison, fined or even executed for this. There is so much you can do with this game.

I've seen some reviews saying that it has a clunky interface (it probably does if you aren't used to the game) but most of these people seem unwilling to learn how to play the game, if you want a simple game then stick to candy crush. I will repeat it is not perfect, you will probably find many bugs but there isn't anything that makes it unplayable and it can be very entertaining if you let it!

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played. Mostly in multiplayer. I remember the old times with timeout issues. They are mostly gone, but there are till some bugs. I'm glad developers are still working on it. It even has a fairly big modding community. I've been playing it for a long time, got it in a computer magazine, and I've decided to support the developers once more, so I've bought it on steam. I realise that there were lot of different companies running The Guild since Europa 1400.

This game has a great potential. It's one of the most complex games, but yet it is easy to play, but difficult to master.
It's an economic simulator.
At the beginning you create your character, there are not many options in design, but this is not The Sims. The more important things are the stats and class. You can even chose between 2 religions, protestant and catholic, the only difference in my opinion is that you can only build church of your religion. You can change it in a church.

So to the classes: there are four of them: Patron, Craftsman, Rogue and Scholar.
They are not balanced. The devs and modders are trying to fix it, but it's still not it. I hope guild 3 will be better balanced.
My first try was Rogue (obviously). It was the easiest way to accumulate a lot of money, get rid of concurrence and hold the highest position in the council. In fact, in about 30 years, I've had a huge mansion on a hill and I stopped playing.
That's the biggest problem of the game. In singleplayer, it gets repetitive.

Scholar is second easier, maybe even easiest, because you don't break the law for your job. But you should. Where is the fun? :D
You just build a church and people pay you just to go in there. You can easily make friends and make everybody hate your enemies. I personally like the cemetery, because of all the satanists praying there. Even more than in church.

Craftsman is my favorite, because it has a lot of challenge, mostly in big cities flooded with concurence. The job of a craftsman is to make something from something else. That's different from patron and scholar who just collects their materials, and rogue who steals it.

I don't play for patron much, because I find it boring. So no review of that profession.

Every profession is necesarry in a town, maybe except of the rogue. Without patron, craftsman cannot produce clothes and so on, and scholar cannot make medicine or other stuff. It is probably the most frequent reason of dying or bankrupting. No scholar means no hospital, what almost certainly means death. I hate that AI does'n really have a stock of more expensive medicine.

Overall AI isn't so Intelligent, but in recent updates and modpacks it is more agressive and more complex. I hope that it will be better in The Guild 3.

So I think that's enough for now, nobody is reading it anyway, I will maybe write another one regarding some other features, like marriage, children, burning down your neighbours house or kidnapping your mother in law.

I'm really looking forward to The Guild 3, in fact, I would gladly do alpha/beta testing.

reviewText:
(Taken from my Guild 2 Review)

This game claims to be an RPG... it isn't. What it is is a management sim and it ain't a very deep one at that. For something that's supposed to be about you living the medieval life there's not an awful lot of you livin' a life and probably a bit too much of you micro-managing your businesses and your employees. It is possible to set the AI to manage the buisnesses you build but you're very unlikely to make a sustanible profit doing that.

The political system seems interesting at first but once you've climbed to the top it doesn't feel very fulfilling, and it doesn't add anything to the game to make you want to continue playing longer.

The family system could've been interesting if it wasn't for the fact that it requires almost no effort what-so-ever. The most complicated thing you'll do is court your mate, but all that consists of is using four or five actions in the right order to increase your prospective spouse's affection, but each of these actions have a linked cool down with the rest so you have to wait a good few hours of ingame time (you can speed up the clock thankfully) before you can perform the next compliment. Children you send to school with a push of a button and there's no need to keep either parent at home to look after them either.

Combat does exist in this game as does criminal actions but it's all rather pointless, you'll be far more successful running a lawful business than you ever would a criminal one and using actions like threats or murder are far too risky and made pointless by the fact that you can just bribe anyone and everyone into liking you.

I find it hard to decide whether or not to recommend this game. Yes i've been critical but as a management game it's not bad and i've certainly played worse. It does carry an interesting premise, if not a particularly well implimented one. What it comes down to with me is, tho, the fact that it claims to be an RPG and a medieval life simulator and it's just not.

A word of advice if you still wish to pick this game up go for the Renaissance stand-alone expansion since it has everything that both the main game and the Pirates expansion offers.

reviewText:
The Guild is a charming series of games. You get to choose a job from a list of medieval professions and build a little dynasty around your business ventures. The resulting story arcs are very entertaining, very much like the kind you get in Crusader Kings. However, in Guilds you don't have to worry about commanding armies. You get to concentrate on all that juicy stuff; parties, trials, sabotage, courting, lampoons, heresy and MONEY.

The Guild II is okay, but I personally think that the first game is actually better than the sequel, because it's more atmospheric and compact. The interface is less confusing and movement is easy since you don't have to move your little avatar around the town in order to get things done.

These games are old, so the graphics aren't going to blow your mind. But who cares, if you can make a pact with the devil and sacrifice your first born so you can finally become a lease master or whatever even though everyone in the city despises you. It's amazing what you can get away with. I dug up my father's grave the very night he was buried.

reviewText:
This game touched on a lot of great ideas. It combines an economic simulation with building up a dynasty by giving you control over the individuals and their abilities.  The problem is it feels like an alpha. Even if the latest beta patch did improve the game in terms of glitches and crashes, the barebone mechanics will drive you insane.

For example, at the forefront of this game sits trading. The tools given to you for this purpose will just infuriate you. Sure, you can micromanage the trade routes in your chain of production, but this aspect is barely implemented. It's pointless to explain, but bottom line you'll find yourself tweaking the routes over and over again. The game doesn't handle properly overproduction mixed with multiple goods to transfer, partial mid route dropoffs are broken, starting the route only allows you to select the quantity of goods present in your buildings at that moment in time, and the list can go on. You'll end up transporting only one type of goods between point A and B. You can turn on the AI for this, but if you do, expect to get even more frustrated. The AI is making dumb decisions such as dropping off finished goods back to the building that produced the original raw resource (probably because it was in the way, who knows), buying goods from the market even though you have buildings that produce the goods in your production chain, filling up your buildings with raw materials leaving no room for the finished goods. Oh don't worry, this is not the only aspect lacking in the game, but it's by far the most important.

This game is the perfect example of stretching the goals and having to deal with a scope creep that got out of control, leading to something that simply can't be called a finished product.

I have been a big gan of The Guild since i first touched the guild 1 years and years ago. I have all of them on cd still but decided to buy the steam version when it was on sale just to have a back up.

But i want to note this game is not going to be up everyones alley for certain and while i think people should at least try it i know many will be dissapointed.

reviewText:
The Good:  A unique take on city-building with some clever ideas and a unique setting.  Mixing RPG, business management, Sims-style social interaction management and city sim elements into a totally unique genre all its own.  Building a business empire is surprisingly satisfying, and the open-ended gameplay can keep things interesting in terms of character variety.

The Bad:  Balance is utterly terrible, two professions earn flat-out more money than any other, the other two can barely be self-supporting and will take generations (literally) to build to a comparable level, by that time the unforgiving AI will have left you far behind.  The game presents the appearance of great depth, but it's ultimately a rather shallow experience with most paths being dead-ends compared to the most lucrative.  The amount of micromanagement is severe, and often frustrating given the time-scale needed to acheive significant gains.  Gameplay gets repeitive with numerous game-breaking powerful paths (like spamming bribes until everyone loves you, while selling endless stacks of herring), if you try not to use those broken paths the AI steamrolls you.

The Bottom Line:  A great game marred by bugs and poorly thought out gameplay.

You'd like this if:  You're a fan of city-building with RPG elements, you don't mind micromanagement, You thought the only thing The Sims was missing was a poorly-thought-out business sim and the ability to firebomb your neighbors.

reviewText:
I probably have hundred of hours in this game, on steam and when i owned it before in a different medium. At least half the bugs people complain about are not bugs, it is people not being interested in figuring out how the game is played. Are there bugs? Yes, but as a rule it is not all that hard to play around them, and i have successfully played around them for years.

To my astonished suprise though, this game is suddenly being updated. I mean who updates a game 5 years later?! These guys are doing just that. And not tiny updates, we are talking full on bug bashing. Sure it looks like they are taking some fixs from the community mods and implementing them into the game, but they give credit for it and why shouldn't they? I am honestly sick and tired of unofficial patches fixing all the things a company is too lazy to do themselves. Especially when most of the work is done for you. Thank you Guild II devs, you are geniuses.

This game is massively complicated, with so many different game mechanics you will have to completely relearn it when you change classes. Sometimes these varying mechanics can be so complicated and different you will find yourself scouring the internet to find answers on how and what to do. A bad thing? Maybe. Even after hundreds of hours there are still things i can not figure out, and its honestly irksome. Large portions of witches and wizards and alchemists are a mystery to me, and i have yet to find anything online to explain how they work. So i am assumign this lack of information means others are as stymied as i am. If anyone knows how summoning circles and transmutation works, please for the love of god explain it to me!

If you like the idea of being able to mod your game, you will enjoy this game. It has mods, lots of mods. It is beginning to seem though the intergration of some of the better mods means you wont have to go through the trouble of downloading them, and some are making their way into the game itself thanks to a rebirth by the devolpers.

If you ever loved the concept of the sims, or better yet breathed heavy over medieval sims, and yet felt insulted how easy the game was, you will be in heaven with Guild II renaissance. I wish there were more ways to decorate houses and businesses, but buying upgrades and having them appear is still rather satisfying. Equiping and arming you player characters is fun enough, though i would like a more immersive system and choice of clothes.

What I think game is missing:

- Interactions with NPCS that aren't 100% game plot driven. You can talk to NPCS to bribe them. Or woo them. Or threaten them. But you never really get to interact with this big world for just fun reasons. Give me a Hey bill
date: whats up bro" option please.\n\n- More stuff to make at your job. Does it need it really? No. But it would be nice if they grew the massive economy more to be epically huge and new options to build more things at your shops and crafthalls. I suppose having so much just makes me greedy for more. And in all honesty it is unlikley super difficult for the devs to give us more.  Therefore since the bug squash has begun
recommended: maybe soon enough we will get treated to more a content addition. After all there are lots of unofficial mods out there with some neat things
hoursPlayed:
maybe some will be made official.

- Bug fixes. but these are coming. Some of my biggest long standing gripes are wiped away with the new patches at the end of 2014. I love you devolpers. Seriously i do!

In the end is this game a buy? ARE YOU KIDDING?! you can find it on sale sometimes for $2.50 and even if its not on sale

reviewText:
The Guild 2 with the new Renaissance upgrade is a solid game. Not perfect mind you but solid. If you are a fan of simulation games like The Sims, or are fan of business games then this game can be enjoyable for you.

Pro
-There are quite a few different maps available for play. So finding a change of scenery in the game is possible, but there is no way to create your own maps which is too bad.
-There are a lot of different store types in the game to experiment with
-There is more than just business. Family management and politics are present as well
-The timeline of the game takes place in what I say is a fairly unique setting. Few games of this type take place in that area of history

Con
-Although there are a lot of maps for play the replay value on this game is weak. Much of the gameplay is the same no matter which map you play on.
-There is quite a clear lack of balance between the jobs in the game. Some earn fantastic amounts of money while others make close to zero even with all of there upgrades. As well a new player has no way to know this until they play more of the game.
-The AI is quite weak. They are unable to build or politcally compete with the player in any meaningful way. This means that once the player has gained any bit of power they will have nothing more than limp rivals to contend.
-There are many bugs in this game. I frequently found my family in the game out thousands of dollars because one of the characters could not 'find a path' to a feature. This was just one of the many that were present.

All in all if you like economic games and simulators this game does have its fun. However the fun is limited and its replay becomes shortlived with the lack of functional AI. ** out of ***** for the average gamer I would say.

reviewText:
The guild 2: Renaissance has more depth than most Alabaman gene pools. There is a lot to do and several ways to do many things. I’ve only got about 11 hours into the game at the moment but it has been 11 hours of aggressive expansion and calculating distain for my competitors.

Note: I haven’t tried any mods yet so this excludes them. I also have not tried the rogue bits.

Pros:
-	Fairly deep simulation of economy and politics.
-	Loads of corruption and fun.
-	Opportunities to mess with the unsuspecting.
-	Hours of mechanic learning and production cycle exploitation.
-	Hilarious romantic simulation.
Cons
-	Dated graphics.
-	Not too much in the way of character customization.
-	Somewhat difficult to learn.

While playing this it kind of struck me as similar to an X game (e.g., Terrain conflict, Albion Prelude) in a renaissance world. Player owned supply chains? Check. Lots of merchanting? Check. Having more money than the entire town/sector probably should? Check! It must be an X game. As far as the ease of access goes, with a small amount of time most of the game play mechanics become fairly second nature. If you find the X games interesting and enjoyable, and you kinda like renaissance times, this game should be a winner.

reviewText:
The Guild II is a fine single-player strategy game, but where it really shines is in multiplayer (LAN/Hamachi compulsory), as you conspire with a buddy to fill up all elected positions in each town or city-state, with various members of your dynasty. Once this is accomplished, the game feels as though it has run its course, but the stories generated by the hours-long journey there are fit to rival any Hollywood plot. The sheer number of options given to criminals in The Guild II is dizzying. Kidnapping, murder, bombing, arson, mugging; and these are just some of the options given to civilians, never mind the awful things you can do to rival factions, or even the Royal Family, if you are elected to a post that gives command over the city guards. That these things can be done to a rival family controlled by a human player; that you can have agents stalk other players, to witness their various crimes and report them to the authorities, or bomb their gold mine, crippling their entire production chain, makes this game an absolute joy to play. It really is something special.

If you'd like to read a more in-depth review, have a look at my new site! Shameless plug, etc!

If you've never played this particular franchise before then The Guild 2: Renaissance is for you.

You manage a dynasty which starts with one family member and you can invest, bribe, steal or war you way to making your dynasty the monarchy. Your characters profession shapes the path you can follow with which businesses you can own, however you can have 3 active dynasty members with different profession types (there are four professions to choose from)

The most recent patch removes some (if not most) of the bugs in the single player game, I've not tried the multiplayer however be prepared to setup an LANoIP setup (and be ready to deal with some of the bugs that currently occur from not using a dedicated games host.)

All in all, there isn't really and single game that is like The Guild and it's franchise.  It's worth checking out.

reviewText:
yeah well.. I love these kind of games and couldn´t care less if graphics and sound and such are not state of the art. it´s the possibilities and flexibility that sets this game apart from other trade / politics / medieval industry simulations.

but... and there´s always a but.. this game does lack on certain aspects.

pros:
-a lot of options
(trader, rogue, crafstmen... it can all be done and so much more. very unique blend of RPG and trade sim..)
-decent graphics for a game that old

cons:
-too much micromanagement
in order to have a functioning economy going, you need to almost always manage it by yourself.
theres no safe way (or I just haven´t found it) to really automate the business and structures and personnel to really do what you want them to
which directly leads to the second con
-politics is a pain in the buttocks
in order to gain influence and climb the political ladder, you need to gain influence. but about the only thing that really worked for me (and I tried everything) was to bribe people. which is useless if everyone else does the same.

I dedicated a whole new career save just to gain influence and climb the political ladder, but to no avail.
when you concenrate on gaining influence, you simply run out of money. when you concentrate on making money, you will never gain enough influence.

once your enemies gain enough political influence (seems they don´t have the problem micromanaging everything like I do) they can use their political powers to just jail you, accuse you, kill you, whatever.

I haven´t been able to find any decent late game tutorials and descriptions and I have to agree to some other review I read: the late game purely annoys. instead of being able to concentrate on late game activities like politics, intrigue and such, you will have nothing else to do than micromanaging your economy.

sure, money won´t be a problem. but it won´t help you at all.

it was fun the first hours, but got old, tedious and boring pretty fast.

for the price I paid it´s quiet alright. but if you expect deeper gameplay.... well. maybe you are into micromanaging. then play your heart out, this game´s for you

You start selecting your character, skills and essentially decide how you want to be the surviving dynasty. There isnt really any backstory as such. Imagine this game to be an arena styled game.. However, to win you use politics, business, sabotage, alchemy and more to defeat your opposition.

reviewText:
- Pick a profession out of many possibilities. Sounds interesting!
- Construct your business building which allows you to produce several specific goods
- Produce the goods from resources that you either collect, buy or produce yourself
- Sell goods either at the business or at one of the markets on the map
- Update the building and hire more workers as money permits
- Repeat with as many businesses as you like
- Grow bored

Resources that you can collect never run out. You can send a bunch of workers to pick that same small spot of lavender flowers for decades.

Resources that you grow never fluctuate. I never had a bad harvest.

Production rates are steady, too. I've never had a problem with my workers or any noticable difference in their output.

Seasons don't provide variation either. While the game has nice visuals for the seasons and even tells you that transports move slower in winter, you can harvest just as many flowers, fruits or grain in the deepest snow.

There are only 3 levels of each building and very similar minor updates. I maxed out 6 businesses within a generation of my dynasty and now they are just sitting there.

Goods are often weirdly specific or illogical. A lvl 2 inn can only offer a salmon and mushroom dish for food, so you better get salmon and mushrooms, no alternative. A lvl 1 bank produces copper coins from iron (by magic?).

Goods never spoil. Harvest a ton of fruit and sell them 20 years later, who cares?

Even places that should be about providing services are not. As a healer you earn most by selling soap you make out of lavender.

As soon as you own a chain of supply, there's nothing left to do. Buy a farm, a mill and bakery, and spend the rest of your life moving icons of grain and wheat around, yay!

tl;dr:
Maybe you could have a little fun with a criminal or political career, but the economy and building mechanics lack any dynamic or complexity that might make them interesting or challenging.

reviewText:
The Guild II is a fine single-player strategy game, but where it really shines is in multiplayer (LAN/Hamachi compulsory), as you conspire with a buddy to fill up all elected positions in each town or city-state, with various members of your dynasty. Once this is accomplished, the game feels as though it has run its course, but the stories generated by the hours-long journey there are fit to rival any Hollywood plot. The sheer number of options given to criminals in The Guild II is dizzying. Kidnapping, murder, bombing, arson, mugging; and these are just some of the options given to civilians, never mind the awful things you can do to rival factions, or even the Royal Family, if you are elected to a post that gives command over the city guards. That these things can be done to a rival family controlled by a human player; that you can have agents stalk other players, to witness their various crimes and report them to the authorities, or bomb their gold mine, crippling their entire production chain, makes this game an absolute joy to play. It really is something special.

If you'd like to read a more in-depth review, have a look at my new site! Shameless plug, etc!

reviewText:
The main reason I'll recommend this game is because you get a ton of value for the price if you get it on discount. It's more or less a medieval version of sims ♥♥♥ business tycoon ♥♥♥ political simulator.

+Many types of businesses you can choose to run in the game, each filling a certain market demand, and your town grows as you hire more employees.

+Interesting political aspect to the game, including elections, where you climb your way up the political ladder for more privileges like immunity from the law.

+Many options to dealing with your enemies, including dueling, defamation, taking them to court, kidnapping, or just plain murder.

And now with the cons:

-AI is terrible at managing certain high level businesses. It’s frankly quite broken and doesn’t do what it’s supposed to do.

-Market demand is non existent for certain products. They will remain on the market  pretty much forever and depress the price. The AI doesn’t know how to utilize some of the higher level items and will never buy or make use of them against you.

-Indicator during politics or court sessions not always reliable at predicting the result.

-AI is more or less passive and relatively peaceful, making it pretty much impossible to be killed by one and thus lose the game. Even if you fast forward the game 40 years, the AI even at their meanest doesn’t go around killing people for the most part and while fighting amongst themselves not one of them will eliminate another. If any one of them is going to die it will be because of the player.

My overall impression is that the game had a pretty good and unique concept, but it was executed somewhat poorly. After all the patching it is pretty playable, but still somewhat buggy. Again, the main reason I’ll recommend it is because if you get it on discount, the value you get blows many other games you can get at a similar price point out of the water. Another thing to add is that the Guild 3 is supposedly coming out this year, so you can treat this game a bit like a preview as to what you may expect from the upcoming sequel.

Many people have said, through various locations on the internet, that this is a game that should be forgotten, and the series died at the first game but I can't help but disagree!

Theres something about this game I just love! I think its the difficulty curve.
